questions.text: Which of the following will be expected to occur with increased binding of a hormone to plasma proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increase in half-life of the hormone

Protein- bound hormones are biologically inactive and cannot be metabolized. Thus, an increase in protein- binding would tend to decrease hormone activity and plasma clearance and increase the half-life of the hormone. Free hormone is responsible for negative feedback inhibition of the hormone. A sudden increase in hormone binding to plasma proteins would decrease negative feedback.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who smoked 20-30 cigarettes per day for the last 55 years reports with shortness of breath. The patient is diagnosed with chronic pulmonary emphysema. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in pulmonary compliance

Loss of lung elastic fibers in emphysema leads to an increase in pulmonary compliance and a decrease in the elastic recoil of the lungs. More air trapping results in increased RV, FRC and TLC but VC is reduced.

questions.text: A patient with severe hypertension (Bp 180/110 mm Hg) is referred to you. A renal MRI scan shows a tumor in the kidney, and lab findings include a very high plasma renin activity. The diagnosis is a renin- secreting tumor. Which of the following changes would you expect to find in this patient, under steady state conditions, compared with normal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decreased renal blood flow

In a patient with very high renin, there would also be increased formation of angiotensin II, which in turn would stimulate aldosterone secretion. The increased levels of angiotensin II and aldosterone will cause a transient decrease in sodium excretion, which would lead to volume expansion and increased blood pressure. The increased blood pressure will cause a pressure diuresis and pressure natriuresis returning the sodium excretion to normal so that intake and output are balanced. Therefore, under steady-state conditions, sodium excretion will be normal and equal to intake. 

Increased aldosterone would increase potassium secretion resulting in increased urinary loss of potassium and hypokalemia. 

High levels of angiotensin II will cause renal vasoconstriction and decrease the renal blood flow rate.

choices.text: Movement of ions through ion channels

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanisms is not rate limited by an intrinsic Tmax?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Movement of ions through ion channels

Facilitated diffusion and both primary and secondary active transport all involve protein transporters or carriers that undergo a rate limited conformational change and therefore, have an intrinsic Tmax. Movement of ions through ion channels is simple diffusion and is not limited by Tmax.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is likely to decrease the mean systemic filling pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased venous compliance

The two main determinants of mean systemic filling pressure are blood volume and venous tone. Increase in blood volume increases Psf. Increased sympathetic discharge causes a venoconstriction, increases venous tone and decreases venous compliance increasing the Psf and increasing venous return. Increased venous compliance will decrease the mean systemic filling pressure. Skeletal muscle contraction compresses the veins increasing the Psf.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correctly matched with the mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma. Proteasomes are used to break down proteins. In some cancers, specific proteins are used by the body to kill cancer cells. By inhibiting proteasomes, then, bortezomib allows these proteins to continue to target cancer cells.

Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor – inhibiting mammalian target of rapamycin (with highest selectivity for the mTORC1 complex. Everolimus is used to prevent organ transplant rejection, as well as used in the treatment of a range of cancers

FILGRASTIM is the colony stimulating factor, useful for treating anticancer drug induced neutropenia

Leflunomide is the dehydro oratate dehydrogenase inhibitor useful In rheumatoid arthtitis

questions.text:
Find out the true and false statements regarding beta blockers

A.	Half-lives of hydrophilic beta-blockers tend to be longer than their lipophilic counterparts

B.	Pindolol has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA)

C.	Beta-blockers decrease triglyceride levels

D.	Sotalol is an example of a Class II antiarrhythmic drug

E.	Glucagon can be used as an antidote to beta-blocker overdose
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hydrophilic beta-blockers – such as nadolol, sotalol, and pindolol – are incompletely absorbed from the gut and undergo negligible first-pass metabolism. This is the precise opposite of lipophilic beta-blockers – such as propranolol and metoprolol – which are well absorbed from the gut and undergo substantial first-pass metabolism. The half-lives of hydrophilic beta-blockers tend to be longer than their lipophilic counterparts.

Pindolol has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA) – meaning that pindolol does not have full beta-antagonist activity. Beta-blockers with ISA may be useful, for instance, in patients for whom excessive bradycardia has become a problem.

Beta-blockers increase triglyceride levels and decrease levels of HDL cholesterol. However, their risk in significantly exacerbating atheromas is small.

questions.text: An outbreak of hepatitis in a village was characterized by high incidence of fulminant hepatitis in pregnant women, who experienced a mortality rate of 25%. The virus responsible for the outbreak is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Non-enveloped RNA virus

  • Hepatitis E virus is an unenveloped, single-stranded RNA virus spread through the fecal-oral route 
  • Infection with HEV occurs primarily in young and middle-aged adults living in Asia, sub-Saharan Africa, and Mexico, with an average incubation period of six weeks.
  • While the virus is shed in the stool during the acute illness the disease is typically self-limited and not associated with either chronic liver disease or a carrier state.
  • HEV Ag or HEV RNA can be detected in the stool or liver in the earliest stages of infection (when the patient is asymptomatic). 
  • Later serum transaminases and IgM anti-HEV titers are in association with clinical illness The most concerning feature of hepatitis E is the high mortality rate observed in infected pregnant women

questions.text: Image shown here is a recently introduced COVID19 vaccine in India. Choose the correct statement regarding this

  • iNCOVACC has the dual benefit of enabling faster development of variant-specific vaccines and easy nasal delivery, enabling mass immunisation. It can soon become an important tool in mass vaccination programmes during pandemics and endemics.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female presents to the emergency room with fever chest pain and hemoptysis. She came to visit her family from South India, where she works in a goat wool processing centre. Chest x-ray shows widened mediastinum. Sputum Gram smear shown in the image. Sputum and blood cultures reveal large gram-positive rods that form 'medusa head' colonies on standard media. The bacteria isolated from this patient most likely produce
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Antiphagocytic D-glutamate capsule

  • Image shown here is Gram Positive rods – Bamboo stick appearance suggestive of Bacillus anthracis.
  • The occupational history of the patient wool processing, is an important risk factor to elicit on history to aid in making the diagnosis of pulmonary anthrax.
  • Pulmonary anthrax is also known as "wool sorter’s disease" because exposure from handling animal products such as animal hair, infected animal hides, hide-based clothing products, or wool has been associated with infection by Bacillus anthracis. 
  • Goat hair is the most commonly implicated exposure in contraction of anthrax.
  • The spores of B anthracis are very small, once they are inhaled they enter the alveoli and are ingested by macrophages.
  • From the lung the organisms rapidly move to mediastinal lymph nodes and cause hemorrhagic mediastinitis.
  • Once the spores germinate into vegetative cells they will begin to produce the three-part anthrax toxin and clinical symptoms will rapidly follow. 
  • Symptoms initially only consist of myalgia, fever and malaise but rapidly progress to hemorrhagic mediastinitis (widened mediastinum on chest x-ray), bloody pleural effusions, septic shock, and death.
  • Bacillus anthracis produces an antiphagocytic capsule that is required for pathogenicity. The capsule is unique in that it contains D-glutamate instead of polysaccharides.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to several hours of right foot pain and swelling Last night he was working in the barn and stepped on an old nail. This morning the patent awoke with right foot pain near the injury site that has increased throughout the day and is accompanied by progressive swelling. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. The right foot is swollen with some erythema around the injury site Radiographic imaging reveals gas in the tissues. On urgent surgical exploration extensive tissue necrosis is present. Culture from the site reveals gram-positive rods. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for the necrotic effects seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Phospholipid splitting

  • This patient likely has gas gangrene due to Clostridium perfringens (toxin-producing gram-positive rods) 
  • Lecithinase is the mam toxin of C. perfringens. 
  • Its concentration correlates with its lethal and necrotic effects.
  • Lecithinase also known as phospholipase C or alpha toxin, catalyses the splitting of phospholipid molecules.
  • It hydrolyzes lecithin-containing lipoprotein complexes in cell membranes, causing cell lysis (including erythrocyte hemolysis), tissue necrosis, and edema (In contrast, human phospholipase A2 catalyses arachidonic acid release from phospholipid cell membranes in the first step of leukotriene, thromboxane , and prostaglandin synthesis )
  • C. perfringens has at least 12 toxins of which phospholipase C is the most injurious

questions.text: Gram stain of a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample from a 21-year-old male army recruit with fever and headache demonstrates lens-shaped Gram-negative cocci in pairs. Which of the following is the most likely route of meningeal contamination in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pharynx — blood — choroid plexus - meninges

 

  • Neisseria meningitidis is one among the most common cause of acute bacterial meningitis.
  • When the organism proliferates, it enters the blood stream and subsequently colonizes the choroid plexus and enters the meninges causing meningitis.
  • Neisseria meningitidis is transmitted from person to person by respiratory droplets usually from asymptomatic carriers. with nasopharyngeal colonization.
  • Anyone who encounters the organism may become a carrier. 
  • The carrier state is asymptomatic; less than 1 in 500-1000 carriers develop hematogenous dissemination resulting in septicaemia or meningitis.
  • In meningococcaemia, there may be signs and symptoms of sepsis and characteristic petechial skin lesions.
  • In fulminant meningococcaemia, also known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome bilateral adrenal haemorrhage causes adrenal insufficiency, brisk hypotension, and death

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. The patient has no known medical problems. He works as an architect and owns a cat. He has no history of tuberculosis. On examination, he is afebrile and has no focal neurologic deficits or meningeal signs. An HIV antibody test and an interferon-gamma release assay test are negative. Chest x-ray is normal. An MRI of the brain reveals a 2 5-centimeter cyst within the left sylvian fissure that has minimal enhancement and no associated edema. Which of the following is the most likely means of acquisition of the infection responsible for this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Exposure to infected stool.

  • This patient has no underlying immunocompromising conditions had a seizure and is found to have a cystic brain lesion on MRI. 
  • This presentation is most consistent with neurocysticercosis caused by ingestion of the larvae of Taenia solium, the pork tapeworm.
  •  The eggs are usually ingested from the stool of tapeworm earners, not through consumption of infected uncooked pork (contains the larval cysts but not the eggs).
  • Embryos attach to the wall of the small intestine and migrate hematogenously to tissues, including the brain, where they form cysticerci. fluid-filled cysts surrounding the invaginated scolex (head of tapeworm with booklets).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department with bloody sputum. A few weeks later he progresses to renal failure with significant hematuria and hypertension. A renal biopsy shows linear immunofluorescence. Which of the following types of hypersensitivity reaction is this patient experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type II Hypersensitivity

  • This patient has Goodpasture syndrome, which is an autoimmune condition defined by the triad of glomerulonephritis (usually rapidly progressive or crescentic), pulmonary hemorrhage, and anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibody formation. 
  • It can also be referred to as anti-GBM antibody disease. 
  • This is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction in which antibody binds to antigen on a cell, leading to lysis by complement or phagocytosis. 
  • Because the damage in this disease is caused by the actions of antibodies on the GBM, diagnosis is made by immunofluorescence, which shows smooth linear staining along the basement membrane.

questions.text: An alleged accused pleads in the court that at the time of committing the offence he Could not differentiate that what he is doing is illegal. This defense for him is available in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The defense where an alleged accused pleads that they "could not differentiate that what he is doing is illegal" at the time of committing the offence, falls under the general exceptions related to mental state.

C. Section 20 BNS: This section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, directly corresponds to the former Section 84 IPC. It provides a defense for an "Act of a person with mental illness," stating that nothing is an offence if done by a person who, due to mental illness, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that it is wrong or contrary to law. This perfectly aligns with the described scenario.

Let's briefly look at why the others are incorrect:

A. Section 21 BNS: This section in BNS deals with involuntary intoxication, not a general inability to understand legality due to mental illness.

B. Section 131 BNSS: This section in the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS), 2023 (the new CrPC), pertains to the dispersal of unlawful assemblies by civil force and is a procedural aspect, not a defense against criminal charges.

D. Section 112 BSA: This section in the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA), 2023 (the new Evidence Act), deals with presumptions regarding consent in certain sexual offense cases and is an evidentiary rule, not a defense.

questions.text: A 16-year old boy comes to the emergency department due to sore throat and fever.He started having a mild sore throat after returning from summer camp about a week ago, and it has worsened in the last 2 days The patient also has right neck pain and earache but no cough or shortness of breath. He does not smoke tobacco or illicit drugs and is not sexually active. Temperature is 38.8 C (102 F): blood pressure is 118/74 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min. Enlarged and tender cervical lymph nodes are present. The patient is not able to fully open his mouth, but examination of the oral cavity shows pooling of saliva a large right tonsil with swelling of the right soft palate: and deviation of the uvula to the left. Ear examination shows normal tympanic membranes. A rapid test for Streptococcus pyogenes is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Peritonsillar abscess

Ref–Read the text below

Sol:

This patient has fiver, pharyngeal pain, and earache suggesting a possible peritonsillar abscess (PTA), also known as quinsy: is an acute bacterial infection of the region between the tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles. It begins as persistent tonsillitis/pharyngitis and progresses to cellulitis/phlegmon: with pus collecting into an abscess within a week of symptom onset. PTA is most common in older adolescents and young adults and drugar alcohol use increases the risk.
 
Examination findings in PTA can include spasm of the jaw muscles (trismus) (which often limits the physical examination): muffled "hot potato" voice, and sv/falling of peritonsillar tissue with deviation af the uvula to the contralateral side Treatment involves needle aspiration or Incision and drainage plus antibiotic therapy to cover Group A hemolytic streptococci and respiratory anaerobes

LATERAL SINUS THROMBOPHLEBITIS

•    Inflammation with subsequent thrombus formation of the sigmoid and/or transverse sinus

•    “Picket fence” spiking fevers

•    Griesinger’s sign (pain over mastoid from occlusion of the mastoid emmisary vein)

questions.text: Intranasal examination shows bilaterally symmetrical, bluish, fluctuant swelling in the anterior part of the nasal septum; this is suggestive of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Septal hematoma.

Ref:Read the text below.

Sol:-

•	A nasal septal hematoma occurs when blood collects in the space between the septal cartilage and the overlying mucoperichondrium.

•	It is classically bilateral and follows nasal trauma, although bleeding disorders, violent sneezing and anticoagulant drugs like aspirin and warfarin are also attributed to its development. 

•	The buckling force strips the perichondrium off the cartilage, tearing the submucosal blood vessels, resulting in a hematoma. 

•	If not drained immediately, the cartilage may undergo necrosis as it is deprived of its nutrition, leading to saddle nose deformity, supra tip collapse and columellar retraction. Undue delay in diagnosis and treatment can also lead to septal abscess, septal perforation and direct spread of infection to cavernous sinus via emissary veins. 

•	Hence, all patients with nasal trauma should be evaluated for septal hematoma, and immediate surgical drainage along with nasal packing for 2–3 d (to prevent recurrence) is warranted to avoid complications.

Alzheimer’s disease is a neuro-degenerative disorder characterised by Neuro-fibrillary tangles (NFT-also called tau/tangles) and Senile plaques disproportionate to age. The number of NFT correlates with severity of the disease.  

The average age of onset is 65 years and is estimated to the third most common cause of death in the US, behind heart disease and cancer.  It is the most common cause of dementia among older adults. The damage begins in the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex causing anterograde amnesia before causing generalised atrophy of the brain responsible for retrograde amnesia.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female junior doctor presents to ER with pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. Her ABG shows Pao2 of 55mm of Hg . She uses OCP. Her vital signs are: BP- 86/44 mmHg, P- 130/ min, RR- 30 /min, SpO2 85% on room air. Her ECHO reveals RV hypokinesia. CT chest is shown 

What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anticoagulation plus thrombolysis

Patient is presenting with massive pulmonary embolism plus with ongoing hypotension, right ventricular dysfunction, and hypoxemia - In this setting, the patient should receive circulatory support, anticoagulation with  fibrinolysis, if there are no contraindications.

The recommended fibrinolytic regimen is recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA). 

Heparin should be continued with the fibrinolytic to prevent a rebound hypercoagulable state with dissolution of the clot.

If the patient had contraindications to fibrinolysis and was unable to be stabilized with vasopressor support, referral for surgical embolectomy should be considered.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient presented with rapid increase in size of thyroid for last 2 months with palpable neck nodes. He has developed hoarseness and Dysphagia too and Pemberton sign is positive. X Ray showed scabbard trachea. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anaplastic cancer

ANAPLASTIC CARCINOMA: 5% - 10% OF ALL MALIGNANCIES.

  • Peak onset age 65 and older.
  • Males more common than females by 2 to 1 ratio
  • Typically presents as rapidly growing neck mass, rarely painful, most aggressive of thyroid cancer.
  • Can occur many years after radiation exposure.
  • Spread to lymph nodes of the neck present in more than 90% of cases
  • Histologically sheets of cells with marked heterogeneity. Cells may be spindle shaped, polygonal or large multinucleated Giant cells.
  • Distant spread (to lungs or bones) is very common even when first diagnosed
  • Overall cure rate very low
  • Typically requires a very aggressive treatment plan with surgery, radiation and sometimes even chemotherapy.
  • Dyspnoea can be treated by “isthmectomy” but often requires the patient to get a tracheostomy to maintain their airway.
  • All tumours of anaplastic type is placed in type IV.

Prognosis is poor with median survival of 6-7 months.

questions.text: A69-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with an acute UGI hemorrhage following a bout of repeated vomiting. Fiberoptic gastoscopy reveals a linear mucosal tears at the GE junction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mallory-Weiss tear

A Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by acute and sometimes massive UGI hemorrhage. It accounts for up to 10% of UGI bleeds. It is due to arterial bleeding following repeated vomiting (which causes mucosal tears at the GE junction). 

The cause is the same as that for spontaneous rupture of the esophagus (i.e., an increase in intra-abdominal pressure against a closed glottis). 

Causes other than vomiting such as paroxysmal coughing or retching, may sometimes lead to this condition. 

Upper endoscopy confirms the diagnosis. 

Surgery may occasionally be necessary to stop the bleeding.

questions.solution:

Bridging veins 

•	Acute Subdural haematoma – Most result from torn bridging veins or focal tears of a cortical artery. They can also arise from cortical lacerations and contusions or bleeding from tears in the dural venous sinuses.

•	Extradural haematoma - result of linear squamous temporal skull fractures with laceration of a branch of the underlying middle meningeal artery. They can also arise from fractured bone edges or rarely from laceration of the dural venous sinuses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has had recurrent episodes of headache and sweating. On examination she is severely hypertensive. Her mother had renal calculi and died of thyroid cancer. Physical observations revealed a thyroid nodule. Before performing thyroid surgery the woman physician should order :
questions.solution:

•    Transmission of MEN is autosomal dominant so, chance of transmission from mother to daughter is 50%. 

•    “In all cases of MTC, before undertaking upon thyroid surgery pheochromocytoma must be excluded by measurement of urinary catecholamine and VMA level to avoid the potential Hazards.”

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency after having a tonic-clonic seizures at work. The patient reports that he has always been healthy and has never had a seizure before. On further questioning, the patient reports that he has been having intermittent bloody stools for the past 4 months. A CT scan of the head reveals an irregular 3 x 4 cm mass extending from the right to the left hemisphere. CT of the abdomen shows multiple polypoid masses in the sigmoid colon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Turcot syndrome
 
This patient has Turcot syndrome, an autosomal dominant disease characterized by colorectal polyposis and central nervous system tumors, particularly gliomas. All familial polyposis syndromes, predispose to colorectal cancer. Turcot syndrome has also been reported in association with both familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal carcinoma, but FAP is the more classic association.

Individuals with Turcot syndrome often have associated brain tumor. In cases of Turcot syndrome, the brain tumor is often a glioma. Additional brain tumors that have been associated with Turcot syndrome include medulloblastomas, glioblastomas, ependymomas, and astrocytomas. Medulloblastomas occur with greater frequency in the type 2 form of Turcot syndrome.

questions.text: A 52 years old male a case of NHL received 1st cycle chemotherapy with CHOP ten days. He presented to causality with c/o muscle twitches, cramps, carpopedal spasm, paresthesia. His initial investigations revealed hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. What is the most likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tumour lysis syndrome

•    Spontaneous or treatment-induced cell death leads to a constellation of metabolic abnormalities that together comprise the tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). 

•    Although it can occur as a result of ongoing cell death in a rapidly growing tumor, it occurs most frequently following the administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy to patients with hematologic malignancies, where a large percentage of cells are proliferating and drug sensitive. 

•    Cell death leads to the release of potassium, phosphate, uric acid, and other purine metabolites, overwhelming the kidney’s capacity for clearance with resultant hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia and secondary hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia. Significant increases in serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) occur frequently.

•    Unchecked, TLS can progress to lactic acidosis and acute renal failure. 

•    Treatment includes intravenous fluids, allopurinol, and especially rasburicase (when uric acid >8 mg/dL, contraindicated with G6PD deficiency as can cause hemolysis and methemoglobinemia- i.e. male African/Mediterranean/SE asian ancestry)) and temporary haemodialysis.

•    Urinary alkalnization NOT indicated as it can worsen Ca-Phos nephropathy

questions.text: Which of the following in not a content of “triangle of Doom?
questions.solution:

The triangle of doom is a triangle bound by the vas deferens, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold.

This triangle contains external iliac artery and vein, the deep circumflex iliac vein, the genital branch of genitofemoral nerve and hidden by fascia, the femoral nerve.

questions.text: Inspissated bile syndrome is usually seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Excessive Hemolysis in infancy 

Inspissated bile syndrome was the term first used to describe conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in fetal erythroblastosis (massive hemolytsis in Rh incompatibility).

The liver histology in those infants was similar to neonatal hepatitis.

Inspissated bile syndrome may also be associated with  cystic fibrosis, hemorrhage (intraabdominal, intracranial, or retroperitoneal), and increased enterohepatic circulation in various intestinal diseases (Hirschsprung disease, intestinal atresias, and stenoses.)

Risk factors for the formation of sludge include total parenteral nutrition, diuretics, cephalosporins, prematurity, congenital heart disease, hemolytic conditions, and disruption of the enterohepatic circulation, which may be due to intestinal resection 3.

Although cystic fibrosis has been associated, altered biliary dynamics associated with total parenteral nutrition is a more related Etiology.

In some cases, biliary sludge has been reported to resolve spontaneously or after UDCA treatment. Surgical intervention is indicated when the bile duct is dilated to >3 mm with persistent jaundice.

questions.text: Base of the skull fracture presents with involvement of the petrous temporal bone, which of the following important sign:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Battle sign

Base of Skull Fractures

•	Anterior fossa fracture- May open into the frontal or ethmoid air sinuses or run across the cribriform plate.

•	Presents with sub conjunctival hematoma,anosmia, epistaxis, nasal tip anaesthesia, CSF- rhinorrhea and occasionally carotico-cavernous fistua.

•	Periobital haematoma or “raccoon eye” indicate subgaleal haemorrhage.

•	Middle fossa fracture involving petrous temporal bone presents with CSF otorrhea, haemotympanum, occicular disruption, Battle sign or VII and VIII cranial nerve palsies.

•	Battle sign – bruising behind the ear appearing 36 hours after a head injury with a petrous temporal base of skull fracture.

questions.text: Thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1) is used to prognosticate which cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) is a tissue specific transcription factor expressed in epithelial cells of the thyroid and lung, as well as in certain areas of the brain. Recent investigations have shown that TTF-1 is also commonly present in a wide variety of thyroid and lung tumors

Thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1) is a transcription factor that regulates the expression of multiple genes involved in lung development. It is preferentially expressed in adenocarcinomas of the lung and has been investigated as a potential prognostic parameter in patients with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive dysphagia and a decrease in appetite for the past two months. He has observed that he had lost some weight in the past, and he has started developing dysphagia to the liquids now, which was previously only for solids. The patient is a heavy smoker and drinker for the past 30 years. Upper endoscopy of the patient was performed that revealed a 15 mm ulcerated mass close to the gastro-oesophageal junction, and biopsy report says that the mass has cells that have “salt and pepper” nuclei that exhibit molding. What is the most probable diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Salt-and-pepper chromatin is typically seen in endocrine tumours such as medullary thyroid carcinoma, neuroendocrine tumours and pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: After parathyroidectomy in hyperparathyroidism there is precipitous fall in serum calcium level with tetany. This is called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypocalcemia after parathyroid surgery may be due to hungry bone syndrome where calcium and phosphorus are rapidly deposited in the bone.

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker male presents with pain along the right arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the left lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. The picture is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Superior pulmonary sulcus tumors, also called Pancoast tumors, arise from the apical pleuropulmonary groove located superior to the first rib. When these tumors involve the surrounding structures such as the brachial plexus, cervical paravertebral sympathetic nervous system, and stellate ganglion, they cause a group of signs and symptoms that are collectively called Pancoast syndrome. This is characterized by ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain, paresthesias, paresis and atrophy of the thenar muscles of the hand, and Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). 

Pancoast syndrome refers to the collective group of symptoms associated with these tumors, which is secondary to the involvement of brachial plexus and associated chest wall, vertebral, or rib pain. Shoulder or arm pain with associated paresthesias along the medial half of the fourth, fifth fingers and medial side of the hand, arm, and forearm due to C8 through T1 radiculopathy are usually primary symptoms associated. Since they are apically located, pulmonary symptoms of shortness of breath do not develop until later, as the tumor begins to involve more of the lung.

Physical examination findings include ipsilateral facial flushing and sweating due to the involvement of the sympathetic trunk and cervical ganglion. Horner syndrome with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis may also develop with the further extent of the tumor.

questions.text: Drug of choice for Imatinib resistant GIST is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sunitinib

Treatment of GIST: Surgical resection (segmental with 1 cm margin)
Node involvement is very rare (so lymphadenectomy is not usually required).

Imatinib mesylate (selective inhibitor of type 3 tyrosine kinase KIT) is best adjuvant therapy. Used in CD117 positive unrespectable tumour or metastatic GIST.

PET is best investigation to assess response of Imatinib
Sunitinib is used in Imatinib resistance cases.
This tumor is radio resistant

Mitotic index and Tumour size is predominant factor for survival.
Most common site of disease failure in Liver

The targeted drug avapritinib (Ayvakit) might be used instead if the cancer cells have certain changes in the PDGFRA gene.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with severe pain in the left femur. The pain is relieved by aspirin. On plain film, a 0.5-cm lucent lesion, which is surrounded by marked reactive sclerosis, is seen. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Osteoid osteoma
Reference: Read the text below
Sol:     
•    An osteoid osteoma typically presents with severe pain that is characteristically relieved by aspirin.
•    On radiograph, the lesion appears as a small lucency within the bone that is surrounded by reactive sclerosis.
•    These lesions gradually regress over 5–10 years, but most are excised to relieve symptoms. Surgical extirpation is usually curative.

questions.text: A elderly female sustained Colles’ fracture in her right hand which was properly treated. She now complains of stiffness and severe pain in the wrist with cold sensation and cyanosis in the fingers. X-ray of the hand revealed complete decalcification. She is most likely suffering from –
questions.solution:
Correct Answe (D)

Sudeck’s atrophy

Ref: Apley’s ‘Textbook of Orthopaedics and Fractures’; 9/e, Chap 23

Sol: 
•    Sudeck, in 1900, described a condition characterized by painful osteoporosis of the hand. 
•    The same condition sometimes occurs after fractures of the extremities (Colles’ fracture as in this case) and for many years it was called Sudeck’s atrophy.
•    It is now recognized that this advanced atrophic disorder is the late stage of a post-traumatic reflex sympathetic dystrophy (also known as algodystrophy), which is much more common than originally believed and that it may follow relatively trivial injury. 
•    Because of continuing uncertainty about its nature, the term complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) has been introduced.
•    Two types of CRPS are recognized:
o    Type 1 –a reflex sympathetic dystrophy that develops after an injurious or noxious event.
o    Type 2 – causalgia that develops after a nerve injury.
•    The patient complains of continuous pain, often described as ‘burning’ in character. 
•    At first there is local swelling, redness and warmth, as well as tenderness and moderate stiffness of the nearby joints. 
•    As the weeks go by the skin becomes pale and atrophic, movements are increasingly restricted and the patient may develop fixed deformities. 
•    X-rays characteristically show patchy rarefaction of the bone.
•    The earlier the condition is recognized and treatment begun, the better the prognosis. 
•    Elevation and active exercises are important after all injuries, but in CRPS they are essential. 
•    In the early stage of the condition anti-inflammatory drugs and adequate analgesia are helpful. 
•    Involvement of a pain specialist who has familiarity with desensitization methods, regional anaesthesia, and use of drugs like amitriptyline, carbamazepine and gabapentin may help; this, combined with prolonged and dedicated physiotherapy, is the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A child presented with a fracture in his leg. He was admitted and was given traction. He is most likely suffering from a fracture of –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Shaft of femur

Ref: Apley’s ‘Textbook of Orthopaedics and Fractures’; 9/e, pg 861
Sol: 
GALLOWS TRACTION / BRYANT TRACTION:
•    This is used in infants and children with femoral shaft fractures.
•    Indications:
o    Child must weigh less than 12 kg
o    Femoral fractures
•    Skin must be intact
•    Both the fractured and the well femur are placed in skin traction and the infant is suspended by these from a special frame.
•    Vascular compromise is the biggest danger.
•    Check the circulation twice daily.
•    The buttocks should be just off the bed

questions.text: Causes of recurrent patellar dislocation are :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
All the above.
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol :  
Conditions causing recurrent dislocation of patella can be grouped as follows  
	Weakening and laxity of the quadriceps expansion and the capsule on the medial side of the knee. 
	Tightening and contracture of the structures on the lateral side of the knee. 
	Abnormal insertion of the ligamentum patella into a more lateral site on the tibia. 
	Defective development of the lateral femoral condyle. 
	Gross genu valgum 
	Patella alta and breva.

choices.text: Intra-arterial injection of heparinized normal saline.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male undergoes a rapid sequence induction to secure his airway for emergency trauma surgery to fix multiple limb fractures following a serious motorcycle accident. He is very cold and venous access was very difficult in A&E. As the thiopentone is injected into his left hand, the patient cries out in pain and his arm becomes suddenly very pale and cyanosed. What is the most suitable analgesic method to control this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Intra-arterial injection of drugs is, thankfully, very rare. 

•	Where it occurs, it is because of inadvertent injection into an arterial line, or injection into a venous line that is inadvertently in an artery. 

•	It is more likely to occur in the hypotensive, cold, peripherally shut-down patient, such as the one in the question.

•	An early symptom is pain and discomfort on injection of an irritant drug. Patients with distracting injuries, sedation, anaesthesia, or depressed consciousness are at risk. 

•	The drug will fail to have its desired effect, and limb pain, paraesthesia, pallor, hyperaemia, and cyanosis can occur. 

•	Damage is thought to occur due to arterial spasm, direct tissue destruction by the drug, subsequent chemical arteritis causing endothelial destruction, release of thromboxane, and drug precipitation and crystallization.

•	Management strategies aim to maintain perfusion distal to the injection. Elevation improves venous drainage, anticoagulation prevents thrombosis, and analgesia is imperative. 

•	Stellate ganglion block interrupts the sympathetic supply to the limb, producing arterial and venous vasodilation, and analgesia. \

•	Intra-arterial lignocaine may prevent reflex vasospasm but can cause damage itself. 

•	Methylprednisolone and papaverine reverse tissue ischaemia, but do not immediately provide analgesia. 

•	Interscalene brachial plexus block will provide analgesia, but not sympathetic blockade.

choices.text: Is derived from pure cis isomer of atracurium
Is eliminated predominantly via Hoffman degradation
Is associated with no histamine release.
May be preferred over atracurium in epileptic patients as it is not metabolized to laudanosine

questions.text: Cisatracurium all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Cisatatracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker in the benzylisoquinolinium class. 

•	It is derived from a single cis-isomer of the parent molecule atracurium, of which it comprises approximately 15%. 

•	It was manufactured to produce a ‘cleaner’ drug without associated histamine release, and there are no such side effects with cisatracurium. 

•	The majority (up to 80%) of the drug is eliminated via Hofmann degradation, which is temperature and pH dependent 

•	Like atracurium, laudanosine is a recognized metabolite. 

•	This tertiary amine is a known CNS stimulant

•	Cisatracurium is more potent than atracurium

•	However, onset of muscle relaxation is slower than atracurium, in equipotent doses 

•	Duration of action is similar for both drugs.

choices.text: The second gas effect is seen during the anaesthesia induction phase.
Rapid uptake of new gas from alveolus results in increased concentration of all other gases within alveolus.
2nd gas effect causes delayed onset of action of an inhaled anesthetic agent.
This effect is seen with only nitrous oxide and xenon.

questions.text: Regarding the second gas effect when using inhalation anaesthetic agents, all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Second gas effect

•	A high concentration of (newly introduced) gas in the alveolus results in rapid uptake of the gas into pulmonary capillary blood, down its concentration gradient. 

•	Rapid uptake of new gas from the alveolus results in increased concentration of all other gases within the alveolus.

•	Starting to inspire a high concentration of N 2 O results in rapid rate of rise of N 2 O concentration in FRC, and an equally rapid rate of rise of alveolar concentration for all newly introduced gases given concomitantly. 

•	These other gases will be both concentrated and subjected to increased Volatile Anesthetic , and so have a faster rate of rise of alveolar concentration than if given alone.

•	This causes faster onset of induction of an inhaled anesthetic agent when used along with nitrous oxide.

choices.text: It can distinguish between causes of decreased brain activity
It predicts movement to surgical stimulus
Higher values represent more cortical activity

questions.text: Regarding the bispectral index (BIS):
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The bispectral index is a statistically based, empirically derived complex parameter. 

It is a weighted sum of several EEG parameters and provides the user with a dimensionless number which ranges from 0 (equivalent to EEG silence) to 100 (normal cortical electrical activity). 

It records the cortical activity of a patient’s brain and, using analysis, gives a raw figure, higher values representing higher levels of cortical activity

BIS is best described as a monitor of the depth of the hypnotic component of anaesthesia or sedation. 

Bispectral index values

80–100 Awake, capable of specific recall

60–80 Increased sedation, impaired memory but rousable

40–60 Surgical plane of anaesthesia. Auditory processing and reflex movement are possible, but memory unlikely

60-40 deep hypnotic state

40-20 Burst suppression

0 flat line ( eeg silence)

BIS values only give an idea of cortical activity – they cannot distinguish whether a low value is due to anaesthesia or pathological causes of reduced consciousness.

questions.text: A 63-year-old lady is scheduled for total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophrectomy under general anaesthesia. She is an insulin-dependent diabetic and has Parkinson’s disease, treated with levodopa. What would be the most appropriate combination of antiemetics for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Parkinson’s disease is a neurological disease of the extrapyramidal system. 

•	It is thought to be due to loss of dopaminergic neurones in the substantia nigra, which causes an imbalance of acetyl choline and dopamine. 

•	It is treated with drugs to increase available dopamine substrate, using dopamine precursors (e.g. levodopa), dopamine agonists (e.g. apomorphine), and monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. selegiline).

•	Anti-emetic drugs are designed to act at a number of receptors throughout the central nervous system, vomiting centres, vestibular centres, and on the gut. 

•	One subtype of antiemetic is the dopamine receptor antagonists. Metoclopramide, droperidol, and prochlorperazine all act as dopamine anatagonists, and can therefore worsen the symptoms of Parkinson’s disease.

•	Dexamethasone is used as an antiemetic agent, although its mechanism of action remains unclear. 

•	However, in this case, using a steroid as an antiemetic may cause derangement of the blood glucose, and impair glycaemic control in the post-operative period. For that reason it is best avoided in the insulin dependent diabetic.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician complaining that he is "just not feeling like myself." This feeling began soon after his younger brother passed away from cancer 3 months ago. The patient is no longer interested in work or going out with friends on weekends. He falls asleep relatively easily at night but awakes very early in the morning and is unable to fall back asleep. He admits to feeling "down in the dumps," especially when he first wakes up but says that his mood improves a little during the day. The patient often thinks about ways that he could have spent more time with his brother. He feels guilty about his brother's death being his fault "because I am worthless and could not love him enough." His poor energy and concentration have started to affect his performance at work, and he frequently thinks that he should just quit "because I am bringing everyone down." The patient has been eating less and has lost 3 kgs over the past few weeks.  What is this patient's most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Major depressive disorder

This patient meets diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode (depressed mood, loss of interest, early-morning awakening, weight loss, low energy, impaired concentration, feelings of worthlessness, and excessive guilt lasting at least 2 weeks). He has no prior psychiatric history and so would be diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Although his symptoms developed in response to a stressor, they meet full criteria for a major depressive episode, thereby ruling out adjustment disorder and grief reaction.

The death of a loved one is similar to any other serious stressor that can trigger a major depressive episode. 
(Choice A) Adjustment disorders are characterized by increased anxiety, depression, or disturbed behaviour that develops in response to a stressor. Symptoms must develop within 3 months of an identifiable stressor and last no more than 6 months after the stressor ends. In adjustment disorder with depressed mood, the full criteria for a major depressive episode are not met. By convention, if the patient's symptoms meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode, the diagnosis of an adjustment disorder is not applicable.

Not bereavement because symptoms are present for more than 2 months

(Choice D) Although this patient is grieving, his depression symptoms are more persistent and severe than those seen in a typical grief reaction. The dominant feelings in grief are loss and emptiness; in a major depressive episode, anhedonia and persistent epressed mood predominate. The sadness involved in grief will likely decrease in intensity over a period of weeks, with intermittent increases or "waves" following reminders of the deceased. In contrast, the sadness involved in a major depressive episode is more persistent and less specific. In grief, patients experience memories and thoughts of the deceased. A major depressive episode involves more negative and self-critical ruminations, with feelings of worthlessness and
self -loathing.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important diagnostic information that differentiates bipolar disorder from schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Delusions of all types can present in bipolar disorder, as they do in schizophrenia. Family history of affective disorders is not uncommon in patients with schizophrenia, invalidating this aspect as a strong feature to differentiate the two major psychoses. Cannabis use and religious hallucinations can also occur in bipolar disorder. Ever since Kraeplinian concept of dementia praecox was introduced, one reasonable, though not always reliable, feature that differentiates these two illnesses is the absence of interepisodic residual symptoms in bipolar disorder. In the majority of patients with schizophrenia significant impairment is noted even between full-blown psychotic episodes. But note that residual cognitive impairment is increasingly noted in euthymic bipolar patients.

questions.text: A 27 -year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of abdominal pain for the past 2 years. The pain is constant and unrelated to meals. She also complains of nausea and a bloating sensation. The patient has had no weight or bowel movement changes. She has consulted many physicians about her problem and has undergone multiple endoscopies and colonoscopies and an exploratory laparoscopy to no avail. She has been unable to work as she cannot focus on anything other than her physical discomfort. The patient is very frustrated that physicians have been unable to arrive at a diagnosis and pleads for help. Her father died of colon cancer 5 years ago at 65. Physical examination shows no abnormalities, and an extensive laboratory workup is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Somatic symptom disorder

This patient's history and presentation are consistent with somatic symptom disorder.

 According to the DSM- 5, patients have somatic symptom disorder if they have:

• One or more physical symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life

• Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to these symptoms

• Persistent symptoms for ~ months

These symptoms may represent normal bodily sensations or minor discomfort that does not signify serious disease. They may or may not be associated with another medical condition, and concurrent medical illness is not mutually exclusive. If another medical condition or high risk for developing one is present (eg, family history), the preoccupation with any new symptoms is typically excessive. These individuals often use medical services frequently.

questions.text: A 41 -year-old woman agrees to talk with her physician at her husband's insistence. She says, "I've always had trouble throwing things away, especially magazines, newspapers, books, old clothes, and lots of miscellaneous household items." She thinks she may need the items again or wonders if discarded items may increase in value. Her husband is concerned that the large piles in their house continue to grow, making it difficult to move around or find a place to sit. The patient's family is embarrassed by her actions and refuses to have relatives or friends over to visit. She has attempted to clean rooms or throw things away on many occasions but always becomes anxious at the thought of parting with various items. She feels guilty and sometimes cries when considering the toll on her family. The patient has no problems with sleep, appetite, concentration, or motivation. In addition to recommending cognitive behavioral therapy, what is the most appropriate initial treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Antidepressant

This patient has hoarding disorder, a newly defined condition in DSM 5, for which drug of choice is SSRI.

Regarding hoarding disorder, remember the following points:

1. A likely hereditary basis, as many patients have a family member with this condition
2. Stress may intensify symptoms, and the disorder is considered to be chronic
3. Onset typically occurs during adolescence or young adulthood or it may begin after brain damage such as strokes, surgery, injuries, or infections
4. There is generally a significant lag time (years) between onset of symptoms and seeking treatment
5. Cognitive behavioral therapy has been shown to improve symptoms, and early trials with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors have demonstrated efficacy

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a medical cause of panic attacks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Panic attacks can occur in various medical conditions such as hyperthyroidism, phaeochromocytoma, epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmias, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. It is also noted that some medical conditions occur slightly more commonly in those with panic disorder, for example mitral valve prolapse, hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 37 years old P3L3 patient has come with a history of post coital bleeding since last 3 months. On examination, it was found that she has a large cervical growth of 5 cm. It was spreading till the parametrial tissue but not involving the ureters or the lateral pelvic wall. On biopsy, there was a large cell non keratinising squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is the best treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chemoradiation therapy.

This is a case of cervical cancer with Stage 2B. It is not to be operated. It is to be treated with chemoradiation therapy. Advanced cervical cancers are treated by chemotherapy. Early cervical cancers require surgery +/- chemoradiation therapy.

questions.text: A 62 years old post-menopausal patient was found to have an ovarian tumour of 5 cm in the right ovary. Her CA-125 is 1230 IU/L. Staging laparotomy was done and it was found that it was in one ovary. Peritoneal washing was negative, capsule was intact and surface of the tumour was smooth and cancer-free. Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy was done and the histopathology report revealed serous cystadenocarcinoma of well differentiated type. What additional step is required in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No further treatment is necessary.

This is an ovarian cancer with Stage 1 A, well differentiated cancer (grade 1 cancer). Surgery alone is sufficient in such cases. There is no need of giving chemotherapy or radiotherapy in these cases.

choices.text: 1-2 doses for the age group of 9-20 years, 2 doses for the age group of >20-45 years.
2 doses for the age group of 9-20 years, 3 doses for the age group of >20-45 years.
1-2 doses for the age group of 9-20 years, 1 dose for the age group of >20-45 years.
1 dose for the age group of 9-20 years, 3 doses for the age group of >20-45 years.

questions.text: As per the latest SAGE guideline by WHO, what is the number of doses of HPV vaccine required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1-2 doses for the age group of 9-20 years, 2 doses for the age group of >20-45 years.

SAGE recommends updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14

One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20

Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21.

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

questions.text: Endometrial carcinoma which is spread till the surface of the uterus is of which stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stage 3A

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high-risk prognostic marker in a case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Previous pregnancy – molar pregnancy

choices.text: Hysteroscopy guided fractional curettage and polypectomy

questions.text: A 63 years old post-menopausal patient has post-menopausal bleeding. On TVS, there was a polypoidal growth in the fundal region with endometrial thickness 1mm on the remaining walls of uterus. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hysteroscopy guided fractional curettage and polypectomy

In post-menopausal bleeding, the first line of investigation is trans vaginal sonography. If the sonography shows any local growth in the endometrium then the patient is not subjected to screening test called as office endometrial aspiration. The patient is directly subjected to hysteroscopy and polypectomy and fractional curettage which will be diagnostic as well as therapeutic.

questions.text: In order to confirm the diagnosis of suspected cancer, which one of the following growths should not be subjected to biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ovarian growth

If ovarian biopsy is done, it will lead to rupture of the capsule and the probable cancer may spread till the peritoneal areas. So, ovarian biopsy is not done. Exploratory laparotomy and frozen section histopathology are done in these cases.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a tubal patency test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hysteroscopy

Hysteroscopy is done to visualise the inner aspect of the uterus. Tubal openings are visualised well but whether the tube is open or not cannot be commented on hysteroscopy alone. Hence it is not a tubal patency test.

choices.text: Myomectomy in female and donor-insemination for male factor of infertility
Myomectomy and for male factor infertility – pulsatile GnRH therapy

questions.text: An infertile couple was examined and evaluated for infertility since last 4 years. It was found that there was a fibroid of 4 cm of FIGO-4 type in the uterus, tubes were patent. Semen analysis report was suggestive of azoospermia with very high FSH levels. Which of the following is best line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Donor insemination for male infertility

FIGO-4 is intramural fibroid, not touching the endometrial cavity. Removal of this fibroid does not improve the fertility. Azoospermia with very high FSH levels indicate testicular failure. The best treatment of such case would be donor insemination.

questions.text: Ambiguous genitalia at birth is not a feature of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Swyer syndrome

Swyer syndrome is a condition with 46 XY and defective SRY gene. There are streak gonads seen bilaterally. Testes are not developed in this genetically male baby. There are no androgens, so the external genitalia are always female type. There is no ambiguity about such external genitalia.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a possible feature of uterine didelphys?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Recurrent transverse lie

Uterine didelphys is a non-fusion abnormality between two Mullerian ducts. There are 2 hemi-uteri. Sometimes there is obstruction in the hemi- vagina in this case called as OHVIRA syndrome which may lead to endometriosis. Didelphys has no chance of transverse lie since there is no such space available transversely.

questions.text: Which one of the following is used in a case of stress urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Colposuspension

Burch colposuspension is a surgery for SUI in which vaginal wall (anterior) is lifted abdominally to correct the bladder neck hypermobility which is the cause of stress urinary incontinence.

questions.text: Martius flap surgery is used in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A and B

This surgery is interposition of labia majora- fat pad with or without bulbo-cavernous muscle used for VVF, urethrovaginal and low rectovaginal fistulae.

choices.text: Crossing of ureter and uterine artery

questions.text: The most common site of ureteric injury in gynaecological surgery is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Crossing of ureter and uterine artery

The crossing of the uterine artery and ureter is called as “water under the bridge”. The ureter lies inferio-lateral to uterine artery. This is the most common site of injury. Most common type is clamping injury.

questions.text: A 28 years old nulliparous patient has developed invasive mole which was of 2 cm size in the myometrium of uterus. She has one lung nodule (metastasis) of 1 cm size. Her HCG levels are 14000 IU/L. She underwent suction and evacuation 2 months back for a complete molar pregnancy. Which of the following is optimal treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Single agent chemotherapy

As per the table which is previously shown, her prognostic score is 3. Any patient who has score of 6 or less is called as a case of low risk- GTN. Low risk GTN requires single agent chemotherapy only.

questions.text: A 32 years old nulliparous patient has had a successful IVF pregnancy. Her embryo transfer was done on 21st January 2022. The stage of embryo transfer was day-3. Calculate the EDD in this case.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

12th October 2022

Day 3 embryo would mean 2 days are passed in vitro after fertilisation. In a normal cycle of 28 days, fertilisation day is 14th day. So, we should consider day 3 embryo as day 17th of LMP. (Date of transfer – 16 will be LMP). In this case it will be 21st January -16 =LMP. Add 9months and 7 days to get EDD. It would be 12th October.

questions.text: A 26 years old primipara has developed vulval haematoma after delivery. Which of the following vessel must be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pudendal artery

Vulva is supplied by external and internal pudendal artery. Vulval hematoma is due to injury to internal pudendal artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of AMTSL guideline by WHO?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PGF2A

PGF2A is injectable carboprost. It is a bronchospastic agent. It is not recommended for prevention of PPH but it is used in the treatment of PPH.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding HELLP syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Raised conjugated bilirubin

In a case of HELLP syndrome, there is hemolysis which causes increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin and not conjugated bilirubin.

choices.text: Epidural analgesia can not be given since it can cause hypotension
Oxytocin can be given for augmentation of labour
Cut short 2nd stage of labour by forceps.

questions.text: A 23 years old primigravida has mitral stenosis of moderate type. She is NYHA class 1 patient. She has got labour contractions at 38 weeks. There is no CPD. Which of the following is not correct regarding the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Epidural analgesia can not be given since it can cause hypotension

Epidural is very useful and it is the best analgesia method in a case of heart disease in pregnancy in labour. It is avoided in AS and AR due to hypotension. It is given in a case of MS.

questions.text: A patient has taken MMR vaccine. For how many months she should avoid pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1 month

MMR are live vaccines and these vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy. Patient is told to avoid pregnancy for 1 month before attempting pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27 years old Primigravida has hyperemesis gravidarum. Which of the following is not seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hyperkalemia

Excessive vomiting leads to hypoglycemia, hypokalemia and water-soluble vitamin deficiency. Ketones are increases due to starvation.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding complete molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fetus is congenitally malformed

In a case of complete mole, there is an empty egg which is fertilised. There are no maternal chromosomes and this is why the fetus is absent in complete mole. In a case of partial mole, fetus is present but it is congenitally malformed.

choices.text: Double bleb sign – amniotic sac and yolk sac

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect match?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Piskacek sign – lateral forniceal pulsations

Piskacek sign is asymmetrical uterus due to lateral implantation of the zygote. Osiander sign is when lateral forniceal pulsations are felt due to dilated uterine arteries.

questions.text: A 33 years old nulliparous patient has history of 3 abortions at 8 to 10 weeks. Which of the following is not a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above

Rubella infection can cause solo abortion and then the patient gets immunity so recurrent abortions are not seen. FIGO 7 is subserous pedunculated fibroid. Only submucous fibroids cause abortions. Cervical incompetence causes recurrent second trimester abortions. First trimester abortions are not seen in it.

questions.text: What does the → point to on this CT angiogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The → points to the posterior communicating artery (PCoA), which extends posteriorly from the posterior aspect of the intracranial internal carotid artery to the posterior cerebral artery. It can be tiny or absent. It can also be large and continue posteriorly as the posterior cerebral artery (sometimes called "fetal" origin of the posterior cerebral artery).

questions.text: A girl who was born with Tetralogy of Fallot presented to the Emergency Department with fever and drowsiness. CECT is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Frontal lobe abscess 

Causes of brain abscesses include:

•	Extension from paranasal sinus infection

•	Septicaemia originating in the lung (e.g. bronchiectasis)

•	Septicaemia originating in the heart (e.g. congenital heart disease with right to left shunt, bacterial endocarditis)

•	Septicaemia originating with osteomyelitis

•	Penetrating trauma or surgery

•	Cryptogenic.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cyst

questions.text: Identify the finding seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diverticulosis

This image is classic barium enema image showing saw tooth appearance.  Saw-tooth appearance to the colon, usually sigmoid, with shortening of bowel, crowding of haustra and picket-fencing of folds.

questions.text: BLUES & FALLS protocol are used in ultrasound of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

BLUE-protocol and FALLS-protocol: two applications of lung ultrasound in the critically ill.

Two protocols adapted from lung ultrasound: the bedside lung ultrasound in emergency (BLUE)-protocol for the immediate diagnosis of acute respiratory failure and the fluid administration limited by lung sonography (FALLS)-protocol for the management of acute circulatory failure.

questions.text:
During his 1 physical examination following birth at home with the assistance of a midwife, a 5-week-old male is suspected to have congenital hypothyroidism. His parents refused all newborn screening at the time of his birth.

Which of the following may be the earliest clinical sign of congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prolonged jaundice

Most newborn screening in the United States consists of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) with reflex to thyroxine (T ). Because some maternal T is transferred to the fetus, most infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic. Prolongation of physiologic

jaundice, due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation, is often the 1 clinical finding in an infant with congenital hypothyroidism. Poor feeding, due in part to a large tongue, somnolence, and lack of interest are characteristic. Additional clinical findings may include a large protuberant abdomen; umbilical hernia; mottled, cool, and dry skin; extremity edema; and widely open fontanelles. Constipation and respiratory difficulties are common. Over time, growth is poor with delayed skeletal maturation.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old is identified to be cyanotic, with an oxygen saturation measured at 71%. Minimal improvement is noted after initiation of supplemental oxygen.

Which of the following is the most common cyanotic heart defect manifesting in the first days of life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Transposition of the great arteries

In patients with transposition of the great arteries, the aorta comes off the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery comes off the left ventricle. Cyanosis is usually noted on the first day of life and progresses rapidly as the ductus arteriosus closes.

Tetralogy of Fallot is more common than transposition of the great arteries. It will show uponce the right ventricular outflow obstruction is progressive, hence later in childhood (usually after the first few months of life).

questions.text:
An 11-month-old female presents with a 3-day history of increased temperature, irritability, decreased appetite, and malaise. Although she was afebrile on the morning of presentation, her parents are now concerned about a rash that they report has been present for only the last several hours. On physical examination, she is afebrile and appears generally well. A blanching macular and maculopapular rash is present on the upper torso, face, and neck. A smaller number of similar lesions are noted on the upper thighs. Despite her relatively reassuring clinical appearance, a lumbar puncture is performed due to the presence of a bulging anterior fontanelle. The fluid is clear with zero WBCs, and no organisms are seen on Gram stain.

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Human herpesvirus 6

The patient has signs and symptoms consistent with roseola infantum, caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). The disease appears throughout the year with peak prevalence between 7–13 months. A bulging fontanelle may be noted in as many as 25% of all infants and young children with this disorder, prompting additional evaluation for meningitis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is admitted to the intensive care unit with altered mental status, fever, and rash. Cerebrospinal fluid cultures are positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Although initially very ill, he survives and is steadily improving. During a meeting to discuss discharge planning and follow up, his parents inquire about potential long-term sequelae of his infection.

Which of the following represents the most common complication in children who survive an episode of bacterial meningitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hearing loss

choices.text: Bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis associated with fissured, dry, cracked, and erythematous lips and cervical adenopathy
Multiple, small, maculopapular erythematous lesions involving mainly the hands and feet
A petechial rash on the extremities with prominence over the wrists and ankles and associated with edema of the hands and feet
Multiple, grouped, vesicular lesions (some of which have ulcerated) covering the tongue and buccal mucosa and associated with gingival edema and erythema
A confluent erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and associated with coryza and conjunctivitis

questions.text:
A 16-month-old boy presents with a 48-hour history of subjective fever, cough, decreased activity, and decreased appetite. Findings on physical examination are limited to numerous small, irregular, erythematous spots with a minute, bluish-white center located on the buccal mucosa.

Which of the following clinical findings is most likely to be identified in this patient within the next several days?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

A confluent erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and associated with coryza and conjunctivitis

The patient has clinical findings consistent with Koplik spots, which characteristically precede the exanthem of rubeola (measles virus infection). Because they resolve by the time the rash appears, Koplik spots usually go undetected unless identified during evaluation of a patient with nonspecific symptoms prior to the onset of rash. A prodrome of cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”) characteristically precede the onset of the rash.

questions.text:
A critically ill child is found to have a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Which of the following is characteristically associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Renal tubular acidosis

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is characteristically associated with a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. The causes of a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) may be recalled by the mnemonic USEDCARP: ureterostomy, small bowel fistula, extra chloride, diarrhea, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide), adrenal insufficiency, renal tubular acidosis, pancreatic fistula.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after his parents noted that his “urine looked bloody.” Soon after arrival, he has an episode of gross hematuria. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells too numerous to count and moderate proteinuria. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. He is referred for additional subspecialty evaluation that includes an ophthalmologic examination. That exam is positive for extrusion of the central portion of the lens into the anterior chamber, macular flecks, and corneal erosions.

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical and urinary findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alport syndrome

The patient has ocular findings often associated with Alport syndrome, or hereditary nephritis, also characterized by intermittent episodes of gross hematuria that commonly follow a recent upper respiratory infection. The ocular findings described are typical of Alport syndrome and occur in up to 40% of patients.

choices.text: Increase in the length of the penis

questions.text:
During a scheduled health supervision visit, the mother of a 10-year-old boy questions when she can expect her son to begin puberty.

Which of the following is the first physical sign to occur during pubertal development in males?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in testicular volume

The earliest physical sign of puberty in males is an increase in testicular volume and reddening and enlargement of the scrotum, beginning on average at around 11.5 years of age.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl with a history of developmental delay presents with her foster parents for an evaluation following removal from her home by a social services agency due to medical neglect. Her height, weight, and head circumference are all below the 3 percentile. Facial features include short palpebral fissures; mild ptosis; a shortened nose associated with midface hypoplasia; a long, thin philtrum; and a thin upper lip.

Which of the following is most likely to be identified during additional evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ventricular septal defect

Ventricular septal defect is most likely to be identified.

The patient has clinical findings consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome, the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability, with an incidence of 1–2/1,000 births. At birth, affected infants have evidence of intrauterine growth retardation with persistence of growth deficiency in height, weight, and head circumference throughout life. Diagnosis of fetal alcohol syndrome is dependent upon clinical findings as there are no specific biomarkers of alcohol exposure. Facial features may include short palpebral fissures; a smooth, thin philtrum; a thin vermilion border of the upper lip; a shortened nose associated with midface hypoplasia.

questions.text: A 34 weeks of gestation male is found to have malformations, atrophy, and scarring of both lower extremities, and cataracts associated with microphthalmia and microcephaly. Review of maternal prenatal laboratory results, obtained when the patient’s mother was in her 6th week of pregnancy, is most likely to reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Varicella nonimmune

The patient has clinical findings consistent with varicella-zoster virus fetopathy, estimated to occur in 0.4–2% of infants whose mothers’ develop a primary varicella infection during the first 20 weeks of gestation; most cases are reported following an infection between 12 and 20 weeks of gestation. Congenital varicella infection may adversely affect the central nervous system (aplasia, microcephaly, hydrocephaly, calcifications), eyes (microphthalmia, optic atrophy, cataracts, chorioretinitis), extremities (limb atrophy and malformations), and skin (cicatricial scarring—often in a dermatomal distribution, hypopigmentation).
